title: General Knowledge Quiz XI (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair across ancient/modern history, biology, math/physics, and culture. No sports content.

items.q: Which ancient Anatolian empire had its capital at Hattusa?
items.a: The Hittite Empire - Bronze Age power known from cuneiform archives

items.q: What script used on Crete remains undeciphered as of today (distinct from Linear B)?
items.a: Linear A - used by the Minoan civilization

items.q: Which pharaoh’s intact tomb was discovered by Howard Carter in 1922?
items.a: Tutankhamun - KV62 in the Valley of the Kings, rich grave goods

items.q: Which pre‑Columbian civilization built Machu Picchu?
items.a: The Inca - 15th‑century Andean empire; site near Cusco, Peru

items.q: What is the Rosetta Stone inscribed in besides hieroglyphs?
items.a: Demotic and Ancient Greek - key to deciphering hieroglyphic script

items.q: Which Near Eastern civilization used monumental lamassu sculptures?
items.a: Assyrians - winged human‑headed bulls guarding palace gates

items.q: Which writing medium made from clay tablets was typical in Mesopotamia?
items.a: Cuneiform tablets - wedge‑shaped impressions from reed styluses

items.q: What monumental stones on Salisbury Plain date to the Neolithic/Bronze Age?
items.a: Stonehenge - prehistoric ring of standing stones in England

items.q: Which ancient city was destroyed by Vesuvius alongside Pompeii in 79 CE?
items.a: Herculaneum - smaller Roman town buried by pyroclastic flows

items.q: Which civilization’s stepped pyramids include El Castillo at Chichén Itzá?
items.a: The Maya - advanced astronomy and calendar systems

items.q: Which 1776 document announced the American colonies’ separation from Britain?
items.a: The Declaration of Independence - adopted July 4, 1776

items.q: Who led the nonviolent movement for India’s independence and was assassinated in 1948?
items.a: Mahatma Gandhi - advocate of satyagraha and civil disobedience

items.q: Which revolution in 1917 overthrew Russia’s Provisional Government?
items.a: The October Revolution - Bolshevik seizure of power

items.q: Which 1919 treaty imposed punitive terms on Germany after World War I?
items.a: Treaty of Versailles - redrew borders and mandated reparations

items.q: Which 20th‑century movement led to the end of apartheid in South Africa?
items.a: The anti‑apartheid movement - culminating in 1994 elections

items.q: What 1948–49 event saw a massive Allied airlift to a blockaded city?
items.a: The Berlin Airlift - supplied West Berlin during the Soviet blockade

items.q: Which 1949 military alliance formed a collective defense in North America and Europe?
items.a: NATO - North Atlantic Treaty Organization

items.q: Which 1950–53 conflict began when North Korea invaded the South?
items.a: The Korean War - armistice signed in 1953, not a peace treaty

items.q: Which 1960s U.S. legislative acts outlawed segregation and protected voting rights?
items.a: Civil Rights Act (1964) and Voting Rights Act (1965) - landmark laws

items.q: Which 1989 event symbolically ended the Cold War divide in Europe?
items.a: The fall of the Berlin Wall - opened on November 9, 1989

items.q: What is the term for mutually beneficial interaction between species?
items.a: Mutualism - both organisms gain fitness benefits

items.q: Which kingdom includes mushrooms, yeasts, and molds?
items.a: Fungi - eukaryotes distinct from plants and animals

items.q: What is the primary photosynthetic pigment in plants?
items.a: Chlorophyll a - absorbs light for photosynthesis

items.q: Which biome is dominated by grasses and experiences seasonal drought?
items.a: Savanna - tropical/subtropical grasslands with scattered trees

items.q: What is the molecule that carries genetic information in most organisms?
items.a: DNA - deoxyribonucleic acid arranged in a double helix

items.q: Which organelle contains digestive enzymes for breaking down waste?
items.a: Lysosome - cellular recycling center in many eukaryotes

items.q: What term describes an organism’s role and position in its environment?
items.a: Ecological niche - includes habitat, diet, and interactions

items.q: Which gas do animals exhale as a waste product of respiration?
items.a: Carbon dioxide - byproduct of cellular respiration

items.q: What is the symbiotic relationship where one benefits and the other is harmed?
items.a: Parasitism - unlike commensalism or mutualism

items.q: Which process converts atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia via bacteria?
items.a: Biological nitrogen fixation - mainly by Rhizobia and cyanobacteria

items.q: What is the derivative of sin(x)?
items.a: cos(x) - the rate of change of the sine function

items.q: Which mathematician proved Fermat’s Last Theorem in the 1990s?
items.a: Andrew Wiles - with contributions by Richard Taylor

items.q: What principle limits the precision of simultaneous position and momentum measurements?
items.a: Heisenberg uncertainty principle - Δx·Δp ≥ ħ/2

items.q: What is the SI unit of energy?
items.a: Joule (J) - equivalent to N·m or kg·m²·s⁻²

items.q: Which numbers are the roots of x² + 1 = 0?
items.a: The imaginary units ±i - solutions in the complex plane

items.q: What is the name of the set of counting numbers including zero?
items.a: Natural numbers (often defined as {0,1,2,…}) - convention varies

items.q: What equation describes the relationship among voltage, current, and resistance?
items.a: Ohm’s law - V = I·R

items.q: What is the base of the natural logarithm approximately equal to 2.71828?
items.a: e - Euler’s number, limit of (1+1/n)^n as n→∞

items.q: What phenomenon splits white light into its component colors through a prism?
items.a: Dispersion - wavelength‑dependent refractive index

items.q: Which theory explains gravity as the curvature of spacetime?
items.a: General relativity - Einstein’s 1915 field equations

items.q: Which religion venerates the Torah as its foundational text?
items.a: Judaism - the first five books of the Hebrew Bible

items.q: Which pillar of Islam requires almsgiving to the poor?
items.a: Zakat - obligatory charity in Islamic practice

items.q: What festival celebrates the Jewish New Year?
items.a: Rosh Hashanah - followed by the High Holy Days and Yom Kippur

items.q: Which Christian council (325 CE) produced a creed affirming Christ’s divinity?
items.a: First Council of Nicaea - resulted in the Nicene Creed

items.q: Which Hindu festival of lights symbolizes the victory of light over darkness?
items.a: Diwali (Deepavali) - celebrated across India and the diaspora

items.q: Which East Asian philosophy emphasizes filial piety and ritual propriety (li)?
items.a: Confucianism - ethical and social philosophy rooted in Confucius’s teachings

items.q: Which Buddhist path outlines right view, action, and meditation practices?
items.a: The Noble Eightfold Path - route to end suffering

items.q: Which holy city is sacred to Judaism, Christianity, and Islam?
items.a: Jerusalem - site of the Western Wall, Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Dome of the Rock

items.q: Which scripture is central to Zoroastrianism?
items.a: The Avesta - includes the Gathas attributed to Zoroaster

items.q: What is the Sikh place of worship called?
items.a: Gurdwara - a gateway to the Guru; houses the Guru Granth Sahib
